summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus opposition memorandum to Ghislaine Maxwell's twelve pre-trial motions in her criminal case (S1 20 Cr. 330). It argues against motions to dismiss based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, suppression of evidence, perjury charges, severance, sufficiency of the indictment, striking surplusage, multiplicity, and various disclosure requests. It also defends the use of a White Plains grand jury.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with six counts including conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury. The Government opposes her pre-trial motions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier with whom Maxwell allegedly conspired to sexually abuse minors. His 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida is a central topic.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who submitted this opposition memorandum on behalf of the Government.

persons.name: Maria Villafaña
persons.context: Former lead prosecutor for the USAO-SDFL who negotiated the Epstein NPA. Her understanding of the 'co-conspirator' provision is discussed.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who executed the Epstein NPA.

persons.name: Andrew Oosterbaan
persons.role: Chief, Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section
persons.context: DOJ official consulted by the USAO-SDFL during the Epstein investigation, according to the OPR Report.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who protested compliance with parts of the NPA after its execution.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Plaintiff in a defamation lawsuit against Maxwell. Her allegations and the related civil discovery are central to the suppression and perjury arguments.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Founder of Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, which represented Giuffre. The Government denies he approached them in 2016 about perjury charges.

persons.name: Peter Skinner
persons.context: Attorney at Boies Schiller who contacted the USAO-SDNY in 2016.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Attorney for Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 and had a follow-up call in May 2016.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Spokesman for Maxwell who called Giuffre's claims 'obvious lies,' giving rise to the defamation suit.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge of the SDNY who modified the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell to allow compliance with the Government's subpoena to Boies Schiller.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied the Government's application to modify a protective order in a separate civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein).

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Former judge overseeing Giuffre v. Maxwell who entered the original protective order. He passed away before ruling on the Government's modification application.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge who ordered Maxwell's deposition transcripts unsealed.

persons.name: Minor Victim-1
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the Indictment. First agreed to be interviewed by the USAO-SDNY in September 2019.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the Indictment. Allegedly received a massage from Maxwell. Was interviewed previously by the FBI.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the Indictment. First agreed to be interviewed by the USAO-SDNY in August 2019. Her experiences are part of the conspiracy charges.

persons.name: Michael Casey
persons.context: Purported agent of Minor Victim-1 who died in 2017. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Palm Beach Police Department detective who died in 2018. The defense claims his testimony about the prior investigation would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: Bernard R. Siskin
persons.context: Expert who prepared an affidavit on jury composition statistics for the Government in a related case.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to sexually abuse minors. Maxwell is accused of assisting, facilitating, and contributing to Epstein's abuse.
Maxwell was the defendant in a defamation lawsuit filed by Giuffre, which settled in 2017. Maxwell's depositions in that case form the basis of the perjury charges.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, executed the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.
Villafaña was the lead prosecutor who negotiated the NPA with Epstein for the USAO-SDFL.
Skinner, along with Edwards and Pottinger, met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 to present information about Epstein.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and interacted with Minor Victim-1 on multiple occasions as part of the conspiracy.
Maxwell is alleged to have given Minor Victim-2 a massage, which is an overt act in the conspiracy and the basis for a perjury charge.
Maxwell is alleged to have befriended and groomed Minor Victim-3, introducing her to Epstein and encouraging massages that led to sex acts.
Chief Judge McMahon issued an order modifying the protective order, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with the Government's subpoena.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, immunizing him and named co-conspirators for specific federal crimes between 2001-2007.

events.title: Meeting between Boies Schiller attorneys and AUSA-1
events.description: Attorneys Peter Skinner, Brad Edwards, and Stan Pottinger meet with AUSA-1 to present information about Jeffrey Epstein, advocating for an investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed by Boies Schiller in the Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation lawsuit. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Five (perjury) of the Indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed a second time by Boies Schiller. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Six (perjury) of the Indictment.

events.title: USAO-SDNY Investigation Opens
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York initiates its investigation into Epstein and possible co-conspirators, prompted by Miami Herald reporting.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoenas to Boies Schiller
events.description: The USAO-SDNY issues two grand jury subpoenas to Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP for documents related to civil lawsuits involving Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Chief Judge McMahon Modifies Protective Order
events.description: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon grants the Government's application, modifying the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell to allow Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury sitting in White Plains, SDNY, returns a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with six counts.

events.title: Superseding Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returns a superseding indictment with the same charges as the original, with ministerial corrections.

events.title: Maxwell's April 2016 Deposition Unsealed
events.description: Following an order by Judge Preska and affirmation by the Second Circuit, Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript is publicly filed.

keyFacts: The Government argues Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) does not bind the Southern District of New York or immunize Maxwell, as she was not a party to it and the NPA is limited to specific crimes in a specific timeframe.

The Government contends the indictment is timely under 18 U.S.C. § 3283, which extends the statute of limitations for crimes involving sexual abuse of a minor to the lifetime of the victim, and that the 2003 amendment applies retroactively to Maxwell's alleged conduct from 1994-1997.

The Government defends its use of a grand jury subpoena to obtain Maxwell's civil deposition transcripts from Boies Schiller, asserting it sought and received judicial modification of the protective order and did not engage in misconduct.

The Government opposes severance of the perjury counts (Five and Six) from the substantive sex trafficking counts (One through Four), arguing they are logically connected and provable through overlapping evidence, including victim testimony.

The Government defends the use of a grand jury sitting in White Plains, arguing it was proper, especially during the pandemic, and that the jury selection process did not violate the fair cross-section requirement of the Sixth Amendment.
